link.title: Coronavirus (COVID-19) - Fairport Central School District

meta.content: Educational Materials & Resources CLICK HERE to access K-12 educational materials for students to use during the District closure Fairport will provide free meals to students in need during the school closure. The following locations are open from 11 a.m. - 12:30 p.m., weekdays only, throughout the school closure: Pines of Perinton (Learning Links) Fairport …

a.strong: CLICK HERE to access K-12 educational materials for students to use during the District closure

div.p: Fairport will provide free meals to students in need during the school closure.
The following locations are open from 11 a.m. - 12:30 p.m., weekdays only, throughout the school closure:
The following locations will be open from 11 a.m. - 12 p.m., weekdays only, throughout the school closure:

Lunch for the current day and breakfast for the following day will be available for free to all children ages 3 through 18, at these locations. Please look for a Fairport CSD school bus or District representative indicating where meals can be picked up at the above locations.

p.a: Click here to read Superintendent Provenzano's latest update for families and the community.

Click here to learn more on: Effective, Monday, March 23, 2020 all Fairport Central School District buildings and grounds will be CLOSED to staff, students, parents/guardians and visitors until further notice. This closure also includes all playgrounds and athletic facilities.

div.div: What is Fairport CSD doing to protect the school community?

p.strong: Since the District closure that began on March 16, 2020:

div.p: The District has been closed as a result of executive orders from Monroe County and New York State. All buildings and grounds have been closed and off limits to students and the community. The District continues to reinforce CDC expectations, including masking and employing social distancing parameters with essential workers. The District instituted breakfast and lunch meal program for students in need. We serve between 400-500 meals per day. We continue to monitor and encourage school members to access the Safe Schools Hotline to support personal safety and wellness.

p.strong: Prior to the District closure that began on March 16, 2020:

div.p: Signs were posted in our schools' digital displays and around the building (paper posters) reminding people to wash their hands and practice good hygiene. Everyone can help prevent the spread of infectious diseases.

p.span: The District frequently cleans and disinfects all areas that students and staff use daily. This includes school buses, which are cleaned daily. Furthermore, the District deep cleans each weekend. The general cleaner that the District uses is a multipurpose cleaner and disinfectant.

div.p: District staff members were taking extra time throughout the school day to allow students to wash their hands, specifically around lunch, recess and physical education classes. Beginning the week of March 16, 2020 the District is bringing in 24 portable hand washing stations for high traffic areas.
We will continue to follow national, state, and county health department guidelines in an effort to keep our community members safe.

div.div: How can we minimize the spread of illness?

div.p: The NYSDOH recommends the following ways to minimize the spread of all respiratory viruses:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when coughing or sneezing. If you use a tissue, throw it in the trash.
Routinely clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Social distance at least 6 feet from others.

li.a: Learn more protective measures from the CDC.

div.p: The Fairport Central School District will be CLOSED until further notice. This is as a result of the Executive Order signed by New York State Governor Cuomo that requires all New York State schools be closed in response to COVID-19. This closing includes all school-related activities including sports and other extracurricular activities. Please continue to make plans for childcare during this time.

li.span: has exempted students from 3-8 assessments, Regents and world language CheckPoint exams.
This includes NYSESLAT and Alternative Assessments.

ol.li: There will be no face-to-face exams this year.
Each AP subject will have 2 at home testing dates, one earlier and one later.
Exams are being modified this year. Full explanations and testing dates will be released on April 3rd.

Initial outlines of the exam are now:
Students will take a 45-minute online free-response exam at home. They will be offered two online testing dates for each exam (AP informational site here).
It will focus on the material that "most teachers would have covered through March" (each exam has a list of topics/units that they will not discuss this year)
Exams will be designed to work on phones, tablets or computers

hr.p: This website will let you know which topics will be covered (it won't be all of them).

p.a: Click here to read the update from Fairport High School to families on April 3, 2020

hr.p: This suspension for the remainder of the school year applies to the following New York State testing programs:

ul.li: New York State Grades 3-8 English Language Arts Test;
New York State Grades 3-8 Mathematics Test;
New York State Grade 4 Elementary-Level Science Test;
New York State Grade 8 Intermediate-Level Science Test;
New York State English as a Second Language Achievement Test (NYSESLAT) in Grades K-12; and
New York State Alternate Assessment (NYSAA) for students with severe cognitive disabilities in Grades 3-8 and high school.

hr.p: All June 2020 New York State Regents exams have been canceled.

a.b: June Regents Exams Canceled, Graduation Guidance Updated

div.div: How is the District supporting educational opportunities online during the closure?

p.span: As we abruptly transitioned to closure, the District’s initial goal was to distribute academic materials to ensure all students had access to educational activities. We were able to distribute laptop devices to students in grades 6-12 who expressed a need.

The District does not have an established online learning program in which students can interact fluidly with documents and their teachers. Teachers, however, are using multiple digital tools to interact with students such as, but not limited to, Google Classroom, Seesaw, Google Meet, and email to exchange information, provide reinforcement and feedback with content and connect with students.

As we moved to the next phase of this extended closure that began the week of April 6, we continue to build upon our digital presence and provide opportunities to further relevant curriculum and content as the COVID-19 situation evolves. We will also begin distributing laptops to our elementary students in need of a device.

As a public school our primary responsibility is to provide a free and appropriate education to all students. Although we are able to loan out computers to some students, we are not a 1:1 device District and we cannot guarantee that all of our students will have online access, even though Spectrum is offering free Wi-Fi during the closure period. However, we have deployed over 600 devices to K-12 students who need the technology to complete the online educational opportunities presented by teachers.

Our Curriculum and Instruction Department and teachers throughout our District continue to make intentional efforts to connect with their students using multiple digital modalities. You will see interactions increase as we move along.

While there are benefits of online platforms worth considering as we move forward, it is not something an organization, particularly given the size of our District, can implement at a moment’s notice. Given our current state, we will continue with our “hybrid” approach of having materials available in multiple formats to ensure access and equity for all students. If you are having difficulty accessing materials digitally and printing, please contact your child’s principal.

div.div: How will Fairport grade and measure student progress?

p.b: Fairport CSD COVID-19 Grading & Reporting Plan

p.span: During the extended closure and COVID-19 pandemic, the District recognizes the need to approach grading and reporting differently. Through our ThoughtExchange and interactions with staff and PTSA groups we confirmed that there are a variety of expectations and opinions on this topic. We are committed to developing a grading and reporting plan that is fair, equitable, credible and grounded in best practice of assessment.

Using the lens of our Fairport whole-child mindset, the collective wisdom of our Monroe County counterparts, NYSED guidance and principles of best assessment practices, the information below details our grading and reporting plan as a result of COVID-19.

p.b: K-5 Elementary Grading & Reporting Guidelines for the final instructional period

li.span: The instructional period will conclude on
Narrative reports will be generated by the classroom teacher that will summarize the essential learning and comment on student progress.

In the event that a student is not engaging in instruction, the teacher will work with the building administrator to ensure that the student has the appropriate resources and abilities to access materials.

The third quarter ended on March 13. As we closed the grading books, our mission was to ensure that the school closure did not negatively impact any student’s grades. Students had until April 15 to submit late work. If students were unable to submit late work, they will be given an alternate activity or if there are unique circumstances, be exempt from the missing assignment.
li.b: Grades will be available for students and parents on April 27.

li.span: Except for Dual Credit Courses (SUPA, GCC, SUNY and MCC), grading practices must proceed as required by these colleges in order to earn dual credit.
For most courses (including AP courses), students can receive a “grade” of Pass (P) or Incomplete (I) and
Students must complete assignments (evidence) to demonstrate understanding of the essential learning outcomes for the course.
Students who receive an Incomplete for Quarter 4 will have
to submit evidence and change the Incomplete to Pass.

In the event that a student is not completing assignments and not providing enough evidence to determine a “Pass,” the teacher will work with the student’s administrator to ensure the student has the appropriate resources and abilities to access materials before grading as Incomplete.
If there are unique circumstances where work cannot be completed, please contact your child’s administrator.
For Dual Credit Courses (SUPA, GCC, SUNY and MCC), grading practices must adhere to the standards established by colleges in order for students to earn dual credit.

b.i: As we move closer to June and understand the extent of closure, this date will be confirmed and communicated.

p.span: notations and final grade point average calculations continue to evolve as we collaborate with colleges, universities, and NCAA to ensure students are not disadvantaged in future admission and scholarship applications.
p.b: As we move closer to June and understand the extent of closure, this date will be confirmed and communicated.

p.span: Again, this is an evolving landscape. If we learn more information that alters our course, we will communicate these changes accordingly.
A FAQ document is forthcoming and will include direction regarding transcripts and diploma accreditation.

a.span: If you have questions, click here to submit them to the District

p.span: . We will use these questions to continue to update our FAQ document.

We understand that there are multiple perspectives in regards to grading and reporting. We appreciate your patience and understanding as we navigate this unprecedented event and strive to meet the needs of all of our students and families. Please reach out to us if you have questions or concerns; as always, we stand ready to support our students and families.

div.div: What will happen with my child’s education and academic standing for next school year?

p.span: The District is not focusing on children regressing in school. All children are experiencing this situation and they all will be okay. When we are back in the classroom, we will all course correct and meet them where they are. Teachers are experts at this! The District’s curriculum maps will be adjusted as we manage the gaps in learning from this extended closure.

We do recommend for parents though, that you meet your children where they are at home currently. If they are resisting two hours of learning time, don’t mandate it or yell at them for not following the schedule. If you can focus on one area, it’s this: at the end of the closure, your children’s mental health will be more important than their academic skills. How they felt during this time will stay with them long after the memory of what they did during the school closure.

div.div: Where can I receive social emotional support for my child?

p.span: Our top priority is the social and emotional well-being of our children and families, and that they are feeling safe and healthy during this extended closure.

a.span: If school community members need support, please click here

p.span: to learn more about, or to contact, the Safe Schools Hotline or your child's school principal and/or counselor.

div.div: How will the school budget be impacted by the closure?

div.p: The District is managing the short and long term fiscal implications of the COVID-19 pandemic. The District is currently re-examining the 2020-21 school budget and fiscal outlook. The Board of Education held a special Board Workshop on April 7 in which they discussed how the District will move forward. The District will be altering its course and thinking differently for next year regarding the school budget. Given the economic landscape, education funding is anticipated to decrease as we move through next year.

Join us on our YouTube channel or Facebook Live for our next Board Meeting on April 21. Please use the Facebook messaging feature to share your thoughts on the topics being discussed so we understand what is on your mind.

div.div: Will families be refunded the costs associated with out of District trips?

div.p: The District’s travel company is currently working to refund families the costs associated with out of District trips, specifically communicating currently with the vendors, but due to the COVID-19 closures across the nation it continues to be a slow process. Families who purchased insurance have been asked to complete paperwork to process their refunds. For more information or to check on the status of your child's previously scheduled trip, please contact your child's school principal.

div.div: Where can I find answers to other questions on COVID-19?

div.p: The CDC has a FAQ page on the COVID-19 situation, which can be found here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html.
If you have any questions or concerns, please contact us our website contact form here: https://fairport.org/contact/.

li.a: Talking to Young Children about COVID-10 (PBS)

a.span: Monroe County day care & financial assistance

ul.li: Other School Age Childcare (Daycare): Generations Child Care (585-673-3142)

Office of Children and Family Services: If you are a parent or caregiver who needs child care, please complete this parent need for child care survey. Based on the information you provide about your job, employer, number of children, and financial need, OCFS may be able to help you find the child program you need.

New York State Department of Health (COVID-19) Information
Monroe County Department of Health (COVID -19) Information

ul.li: The New York State Department of Health toll-free Novel Coronavirus Hotline: 1-888-364-3065

div.span:
This website is maintained by the Fairport Central School District’s Community Relations and Technology Services departments.
It is the goal of the District that the information on this website be accessible to individuals with visual, hearing or cognitive disabilities. Good faith efforts have been made to ensure that our site complies with New York State standards on website accessibility.
However, if you are unable to access or use any aspect of this site, please Submit the Accessibility Reporting Form so that we may provide you with alternative means of access or use. Please note, however, that the District is not responsible for facts or opinions contained on any linked site.

b.a:
The Fairport Central School District will remain CLOSED until at least May 15, 2020 due to New York State Governor Cuomo's order in response to COVID-19. All District buildings and grounds are CLOSED until further notice, including all playgrounds and athletic facilities.
CLICK HERE FOR NEWEST April 17, 2020 MESSAGE.
